    Opportunities for Tapping into Three-Dimensional Chemical Space through a Quaternary Carbon

    • Tanaji T. Talele*
      Tanaji T. Talele
      Department of Pharmaceutical Sciences, College of Pharmacy and Health Sciences, St. John’s University, Queens, New York 11439, United States
      *E-mail: [email protected]. Phone: (718) 990-5405. Fax: (718) 990-1877.
      More by Tanaji T. Talele
      View Biography
      http://orcid.org/0000-0002-5938-6505
    Cite this: J. Med. Chem. 2020, 63, 22, 13291–13315
    Publication Date (Web):August 17, 2020

    Publication History

    • Received15 May 2020
    • Published online17 August 2020
    • Published inissue 25 November 2020
    https://doi.org/10.1021/acs.jmedchem.0c00829

    SUBJECTS:

    Get e-Alerts

    Abstract

    A quaternary carbon bears four other carbon substituents or combination of four non-hydrogen substituents at four vertices of a tetrahedron. The spirocyclic quaternary carbon positioned at the center of a bioactive molecule offers conformational rigidity, which in turn reduces the penalty for conformational entropy. The quaternary carbon is a predominant feature of natural product structures and has been associated with more effective and selective binding to target proteins compared to planar compounds with a high sp2 count. The presence of a quaternary carbon stereocenter allows the exploration of novel chemical space to obtain new molecules with enhanced three-dimensionality. These characteristics, coupled to an increasing awareness to develop sp3-rich molecules, boosted utility of quaternary carbon stereocenters in bioactive compounds. It is hoped that this Perspective will inspire the chemist to utilize quaternary carbon stereocenters to enhance potency, selectivity, and other drug-like properties.

    Relevance of a Quaternary Carbon in Modern Drug Design

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Traditionally medicinal chemists have been inclined to create architecturally simple flat molecules.(1−3) This is not surprising because the commercial compound screening libraries employed in several high-throughput screening (HTS) campaigns are enriched with flat and linear (hetero)aromatic compounds with a limited number of sp3 carbon centers.(4−6) Moreover, (hetero)aromatic rings provide numerous vectors that can be functionalized by a robust aromatic chemistry without introducing stereochemical complexity.(2) Substituents, appended to sp2-rich (hetero)aromatic rings, are often projected outward along the perimeter of a disk shaped molecular skeleton.(7) On the contrary, substituents, appended to a diversity oriented synthesis-derived globular/spherical sp3-rich compound, are projected out-of-plane of a spherically shaped skeleton.(7) Although (hetero)aromatic rings appear to be attractive in terms of synthetic feasibility and SAR analysis compared to the sp3-rich scaffolds, too many in a given lead compound will have negative consequences (poor solubility, increased plasma protein binding, CYP450 inhibition/activation, and hERG (human ether-a-go-go-related gene) channel inhibition) in terms of clinical development.(1,2) For example, highly planar molecular features result in higher packing in a three-dimensional periodic lattice through π-stacking, a characteristic that, in turn, can lead to compounds with poor aqueous solubility.(8−10) Flat molecules are metabolically labile largely due to the presence of unhindered metabolically labile sites. Furthermore, flat molecules occupy only a tiny fraction of synthetically feasible small molecule entities within the universe of astronomically large (>1060) collection of molecules with drug-like properties.(11,12) Increased molecular planarity (mostly two-dimensional) provides limited shape diversity and less efficient interaction toward a three-dimensional target binding site.(13) The high (hetero)aromatic ring count has been associated with the inhibition/activation of the major drug metabolizing CYP450 enzymes.(2) Additionally, flat molecules are prone to a high chance of off-target effects.(14−16) Aforementioned shortcomings of largely two-dimensional molecules collectively contribute to a higher rate of late stage attrition of sp2-rich drug candidates.(1,2,14)
    The molecular planarity can be effectively disrupted by increasing the fraction of sp3 (Fsp3)-hybridized carbons while removing aromatic rings from a planar structure.(17,18) This topic has been the subject of many reviews.(15,16,19−21) Fsp3 is a measure of molecular complexity and is defined as a ratio of the number of sp3 hybridized carbon atoms to the total carbon atom count.(22) Alicyclic ring systems are more water-soluble because of increased solvation and poor solid state crystal lattice packing compared to flat (hetero)aromatic ring systems.(1,16,23,24) Consequently, efforts in drug discovery have been directed to incorporate sp3-hybridized carbon centers to allow for more efficient sampling of a larger fraction of chemical space and on target selectivity.(7,15,16,25−27) Small drug molecules enriched with sp3-hybridized carbon atoms with minimal aromatic/heteroaromatic rings are likely to be clinically successful.(15,16,28) It has been shown that an increase in sp3 count in small molecules resulted in reduced promiscuity and inhibition of drug metabolizing CYP450 enzymes.(15) Further sp3-rich molecules may enable targeting of those therapeutic proteins that are otherwise difficult to target.(6,29,30)
    The presence of a sterically hindered quaternary carbon in bioactive small molecules promotes an element of conformational restriction and architecturally complex structures that are shown to impart increased potency, selectivity, and metabolic stability.(4,15,16,23,31−33) A quaternary carbon bears four other carbon substituents or combination of four non-hydrogen substituents that form the vertices of a tetrahedron. A quaternary carbon (spiroatom) is also present in spirocyclic molecules. A quaternary carbon-containing small molecule possesses inherent three-dimensionality that allows for the simultaneous projection/optimization of substituents at the four vertices of a tetrahedral carbon atom.(13) By virtue of chain growth in all four directions from the sp3 tetrahedral carbon atom, quaternary carbon-containing small molecules will allow medicinal chemists to tap into a previously unexplored chemical space.(34,35) Although a precise definition of chemical space is more complex, a simplified definition states that it is a collection of all possible organic compounds.(36) Construction of quaternary carbon-containing small molecules is a formidable synthetic challenge due to inherently unfavorable steric hindrance.(37,38) The paucity of efficient and generally applicable synthetic methods for the construction of quaternary carbon-containing small molecules has restricted its application in drug discovery. Nonetheless, recent publications disclosing synthetic methodologies for the construction of quaternary-carbon containing small molecules are expected to spur further interest in this area of drug discovery.(13,37,39−48)
    A major objective of this Perspective is to encourage exploration of three-dimensional space in small molecules through the use of a quaternary-carbon center by providing rather selected examples and by no means an exhaustive review of the field. Where possible, matched molecular pairs with a concise discussion are provided, and the reader is referred to the original citations for a more detailed information. The last sections of this Perspective will highlight (i) the contribution of a quaternary carbon in terms of drug-like property optimization, (ii) potential caveats of quaternary carbon insertion in bioactive compounds, (iii) examples of quaternary carbon-containing compounds that entered development, and (iv) the summary.

    Matched Molecular Pairs of Quaternary versus Secondary/Tertiary Carbon Compounds

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To

    Discovery of Oxytocin Receptor (OTR) Antagonists 1 and 2

    The OTR antagonism in the brain has been shown to present a potential treatment for premature ejaculation,(49) which prompted Li and co-workers to develop OTR antagonists.(50) Early lead compounds such as 1, featuring a phenyl substituted pyrrolidine ring, demonstrated low nanomolar potency against human OTR, but it showed poor selectivity over vasopressin. It also exhibited poor rat pharmacokinetic (PK) profile (Figure 1). To circumvent the shortcomings of 1, the pyrrolidine ring of this compound was converted into a more rigid ring system such as 3-azabicyclo[3.1.0]hexane to obtain a quaternary carbon-containing (S,S) analogue 2 (SHR1653)(50) with marginally improved human OTR antagonist activity. 2 manifested a significantly improved rat PK profile and selectivity over human vasopressin compared to 1. Furthermore, 2 demonstrated excellent blood–brain barrier (BBB) permeability as evidenced from its concentration (229 ng/g) in rat brain tissue.

    Development of Lysine Specific Demethylase 1 (LSD1) Inhibitors 3 and 4

    LSD1 plays a key role in cancer and other diseases. Consequently, Mould and co-workers synthesized several N-arylglycinamides as reversible LSD1 inhibitors.(51) They reported that the early lead 3 was a potent reversible inhibitor of LSD1 with acceptable in vitro ADME profile and off-target hERG activity. Lead optimization efforts led these authors to conclude that the presence of a para-cyanophenyl (the cyano group forming a key hydrogen bond with Lys661) and the side chain basic nitrogen center (which forms a network of ionic interactions with acidic residues Asp555 and Asp556) were critical for LSD1 inhibition. Further improvement in in vitro ADME and hERG inhibition liability profile and in vitro potency was accomplished by rigidifying the 4-aminomethylpiperidine into the 2,7-diazaspiro[3.5]nonane spiro ring system as in 4 (Figure 2).

    Development of G-Protein-Coupled Bile Acid Receptor 1 (GP-BAR1/TGR5) Agonists 5–7

    Zhang et al. began optimization of an initial lead 5 as TGR5 agonists for the treatment of type 2 diabetes.(52) Chemical modification of 5 involved incorporation of a methyl group at the 7-position of a tetrahydrobenzimidazole scaffold, leading to 6 with a quaternary center at C7 (Figure 3). This modification resulted in modestly improved activity toward mouse TGR5 with no improvement in aqueous solubility and potency toward human TGR5. To increase the kinetic solubility and human TGR5 potency of 6, a favorable C7-methyl group was retained and a tert-amine capped polyethylene glycol group was inserted at the para-position of the eastern phenyl ring to obtain 7 with increased kinetic solubility and potency at both mouse and human TGR5. Furthermore, 7 showed desirable in vivo DMPK profile in mouse.

    Discovery of Diacylglycerol Acyltransferase 1 (DGAT1) Inhibitors 8–10

    DGAT1 is an emerging target for the development of treatments for metabolic disorders. Consequently, Cheung and co-workers developed tetralone derivatives as potent and selective inhibitors of DGAT1.(53) They began with the tetralone derivative 8, which showed single-digit micromolar DGAT1 inhibitory potency. However, the C2-monosubstituted tetralone, as in 8, may undergo racemization due to the presence of an enolizable C1-ketone function, and the electrophilic ketone group is further susceptible to nucleophilic attack. These observations prompted the authors to introduce a quaternary center next to the ketone functionality as exemplified by the trifluoroethyl substituted tetralone derivative rac-9 with a >900-fold increased DGAT1 inhibitory potency. While retaining the tetralone scaffold of 9, they optimized the central and the terminal phenyl rings to obtain 10 with in vitro potency akin to that of 9.(53) Because of its excellent PK/PD profile, 10 was selected as a candidate for further development (Figure 4).

    Discovery of Inhibitors of the PI3K-AKT-mTOR Pathway

    The phosphoinositide-3-kinase (PI3K)-AKT-mammalian target of rapamycin (mTOR) pathway is involved in a number of cellular processes such as proliferation, metabolism, autophagy, differentiation, and survival.(54) Therefore, Hobbs et al. synthesized compound 12, characterized by the presence of a 3-oxabicyclo[4.1.0]heptane all-carbon quaternary morpholine surrogate, as a multitarget (PI3K/AKT/MTOR) inhibitor.(55) The X-ray structure of 12 revealed coplanarity between the pyrimidine ring and the 3-oxabicyclo[4.1.0]heptane moiety. The authors postulated that the oxygen atom in a 3-oxabicyclo[4.1.0]heptane ring is oriented optimally to engage in a key hydrogen bonding interaction with the target enzymes. On the basis of biochemical potency and physicochemical properties, 12 manifested a comparable profile to that of the previously reported morpholine analogue 11 (Figure 5).(56)

    Development of P2Y12 Antagonists 13 and 14 as Antiplatelet Agents

    P2Y12 antagonists were reported by Kong et al. to act as antiplatelet agents.(57) They introduced a methyl substituent at the 4-position of the piperidine ring of 13 to obtain a quaternary carbon-containing piperidine analogue 14 with comparable in vitro potency and encouraging DMPK profile (Figure 6).

    Development of Benzocyclobutene Derivatives 16 and 17 as General Anesthetics

    Zhang and co-workers reported the synthesis of a novel class of benzocyclobutene-based general anesthetics by fusing the isopropyl moiety to the meta-position of the phenolic ring in 15 (propofol).(58) This has led to the identification of the methyl substituted benzocyclobutene analogue 16 with marginally improved therapeutic efficacy and index compared to 15. Incorporation of the cyano group on a methyl substituted tert-carbon center led to a quaternary carbon-containing analogue 17 with increased efficacy and therapeutic index (TI) evaluated using a mice model of anesthesia (Figure 7).

    Discovery of BCL-XL Inhibitors 18 and 19

    Highly selective BCL-XL inhibitors are useful in the treatment of solid tumors. Since BCL-2 inhibition is associated with neutropenic toxicity, Wang and colleagues decided to develop a novel class of highly selective BCL-XL inhibitors.(59) They synthesized 18 bearing the P4-pocket targeted sp3-rich cyclohexane ring. 18 showed exceptional selectivity toward BCL-XL and MOLT-4 cells over BCL-2 and RS4;11 cell lines, respectively (Figure 8). Subsequently, they replaced the cyclohexane ring with a bulkier sp3-rich adamantyl moiety to obtain 19 with improved functional efficacy against MOLT-4 cells.

    Naphthalene Derivatives as Antifungal Agents 20–22

    Nussbaumer and colleagues converted inactive secondary benzylic carbon bearing analogue 20 to a quaternary carbon derivative 21 by inserting a gem-dimethyl substituent.(60)21 had a significant improvement in antifungal activity against Aspergillus fumigatus and Candida albicans strains. Replacement of a gem-dimethyl group with a spirocyclopropane led to 22 with detrimental effect on antifungal activity, which reinforces the fact that quaternization is not a universal panacea for improving drug properties (Figure 9).

    A1-Adenosine Receptor Antagonists 23 and 24

    Adenosine receptors are drug targets for numerous disease conditions.(61) Shimada and co-workers(62) began optimization of previously reported lead 23,(63) which had a low nanomolar antagonist potency against A1 and high selectivity over A2. Subsequent optimization involved replacement of a C8-cyclopentyl moiety with a conformationally restricted quaternary carbon-containing 2,2,5,5-tetramethylcyclopentyl moiety to obtain 24 with retention of antagonist potency against A1 but with substantial boost in selectivity over A2 (Figure 10).

    Two Quaternary Carbon-Containing Bicyclo[1.1.1]pentane (BCP) System as a Phenyl Ring Isostere

    Although BCP has a different stereoelectronic property compared to the 1,4-disubstituted phenyl ring, it shares comparable dihedral angles and similar distance and coplanar linear disposition of the substituents.(64−66) BCP system significantly increases aqueous solubility and noticeably decreases nonspecific binding.(67) Consequently, the sp3-rich BCP system serves as a nonclassical phenyl bioisostere to “escape from flatland” imposed by high aromatic ring count and modulate physicochemical properties during lead optimization.(68) For example, isosteric replacement of the 1,4-disubstituted phenyl ring with BCP has been shown to confer significantly improved passive permeability and aqueous solubility.(66,69,70) Further mGluR1 antagonist development work successfully utilized BCP as an isostere of a 1,4-disubstituted phenyl ring as evidenced from retention of mGluR1 antagonist potency.(64,65) It should be noted that such bioisosteric replacement strategy will not be effective in lead compounds where a 1,4-disubstituted phenyl ring plays a pharmacophore role such as π–π stacking or π–cation interactions with the aromatic or positively charged residues of the target protein.(71)

    Isosteric Replacement of the Phenyl Ring by BCP System in Lipoprotein-Associated Phospholipase A2 (LpPLA2) Inhibitor

    LpPLA2 is a therapeutic target for the development of antiatherosclerotic drugs. Comparison of the structures of 25 and 26 revealed successful isosterism between the phenyl ring and the two quaternary carbon-containing BCP system (Figure 11).(19) Although 26 underwent noticeable loss of potency, it exhibited improved physicochemical profile (including permeability, kinetic solubility, and thermodynamic fasted state simulated intestinal fluid solubility) and a comparable property forecast index (PFI)(72) (a risk indicator of developability). Despite a rise in ChromLogD7.4 for 26 compared to 25, it exhibited increased solubility and thus reinforces the contribution of disruption of the molecular planarity. 26 also showed low clearance based on human liver microsomal stability test. On the basis of the physicochemical properties of 26, it is reasonable to assume that by disrupting the molecular planarity and decreasing the aromatic ring count, the solubility and other PK related properties can be improved.

    γ-Secretase Inhibitors 27 and 28

    γ-Secretase inhibitors have a potential for the treatment of Alzheimer’s disease. Stepan and co-workers bioisosterically replaced the para-substituted fluorophenyl ring in 27 with the BCP system, which led to 28 with retention of enzymatic potency but significantly improved biopharmaceutical properties, including human liver microsomal clearance, passive permeability, and aqueous solubility.(66) Further 28 showed superior oral absorption in a mouse model compared to 27 (Figure 12).

    Resveratrol and Its BCP Isostere

    True potential of resveratrol as a drug has been hampered due to its undesirable bioavailability. To address this drawback, Goh and colleagues(70) replaced the 1,4-disubstituted phenolic ring with bioisosteric BCP system, which led to 30 with improved in vivo PK profile compared to that of 29 (Figure 13).(73)

    Carbon–Oxygen/Sulfur/Nitrogen/Halogen Tetrasubstituted Center in Medicinal Chemistry

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To

    Discovery of GPR40 Superagonists 31 and 32

    GPR40 agonism is a novel strategy for the development of therapeutics to treat type 2 diabetes. Huang et al. reported the synthesis of the trans-cyclohexane ring-containing fatty acid mimicking arylpropionic acid superagonist 31 that showed low nanomolar potency in a fluorometric imaging plate reader (FLIPR)-based intracellular calcium mobilization assay and inositol monophosphate (IP1) assay; however, its PK profile was less than optimal.(74) Insertion of an α-methyl in 31 led to a tetrasubstituted carbon-containing analogue 32 with improved potency and overall PK profile (Figure 14). Although 32 produced a potentially hepatotoxic acyl glucuronide (AG) conjugate, it was deemed safe because of the increased stability of AG conjugate (half-life of >7 h).

    Discovery of Benzoazepine-quinolines as Orally Bioavailable Respiratory Syncytial Virus (RSV) Fusion (F) Protein Inhibitors 33 and 34

    RSV F protein, a surface glycoprotein, is expressed on the RSV envelope and plays a key role for the entry of the virus into host cells.(75) RSV F promotes the formation of syncytia between an infected cell and neighboring healthy cells, an effect that leads to the rapid spread of the viral infection.(76) Therefore, RSV F serves as a molecular target to halt viral entry and spread and thus to a treatment of a RSV infected patient. Zheng and colleagues applied 2D/3D similarity-based virtual screening to obtain several promising benzoazepine-quinoline lead compounds such as 33 with a potent and selective RSV F inhibitory activity.(77) Conformational analysis of 33 concluded that the benzoazepine ring and the quinoline ring must be orthogonal (90° dihedral angle) to each other for activity against RSV F. Further investigation of 33 revealed its poor PAMPA permeability and oral exposure. The reduced permeability of 33 was rationalized based on the presence of a highly basic (pKb) terminal amine functionality. Therefore, addition of an oxetane ring, a carbonyl surrogate, adjacent to the basic amine in the form of a spiro ring would be expected to reduce the basicity (pKb) as in 34. Overall 34 demonstrated promising in vitro potency, selectivity, PAMPA permeability, and improved oral exposure compared to 33 (Figure 15). Docking of 34 into the RSV F protein indicated that the oxetane moiety primarily contributed toward restricting the conformation of the ethylamine head group such that it can effectively engage in salt bridge formation with the side chain of Asp486.

    Identification of IKKβ Inhibitors 35 and 36

    IκB kinase β (IKKβ), a major regulator of nuclear factor κB (NF-κB), is a therapeutic target for the development of nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory agents.(78) Kerns et al. described the optimization of 3,5-disubstituted indole-7-carboxamides as inhibitors of IKKβ.(79) Compound 35 showed promising in vitro potency and PAMPA permeability, but it suffered from moderate oral exposure and short half-life. To address these issues, a gem-dimethyl substituent was inserted on a carbon adjacent to the sulfone group, thus leading to 36 with comparable in vitro potency but improved PK profile than 35 (Figure 16).

    Discovery of ERK Inhibitors 37–39

    The extracellular signal-regulated kinase 1/2 (ERK1/2) has been established as a target for oncology drug discovery.(80) Promising in vitro biochemical and cell-based potency and selectivity were demonstrated by a pyrrolidine-based dual ERK1/2 inhibitor 37 (SCH-772984).(81) However, because 37 exhibited poor Caco2 cell permeability and high plasma clearance, it suffered from poor oral absorption and bioavailability. Metabolite identification studies on 37 showed hydrolytic degradation of the pyrrolidine-3-carboxamide group.(82) The authors proposed that the poor PK profile of 37 was perhaps due to its hydrolysis. Therefore, they introduced a more sterically bulky (S)-methylthio group at the C3-position of the pyrrolidine ring to protect the amide group from undergoing hydrolysis. Other chemical modifications involved replacement of the pyridine and piperazine rings with 4-fluorophenyl and tetrahydropyridine rings, respectively. This strategy resulted in the identification of 38 with improved PK profile compared to 37. The hydrolytically stable pyrrolidine core was retained while conducting chemical modifications on either end of 38 to obtain the dual ERK1/2 inhibitory orally bioavailable, clinical candidate 39 (MK-8353) (Figure 17).(82)

    Identification of Pim Kinase Inhibitors 40 and 41

    Since Pim kinases play a role in cancers, Wang et al. decided to develop pan-Pim kinase inhibitors.(83) They began with the optimized quinazolinone-pyrrolodihydropyrrolone lead scaffold 40, which showed potent pan-Pim kinase inhibitory activity. The authors suspected that the poor aqueous solubility exhibited by this scaffold was due to the coplanar arrangement of the quinazolinone and the pyrrole ring, a situation that is reinforced by an intramolecular hydrogen bond (IMHB) between the pyrrole-NH and the quinazolinone-N. To offset this liability, they decided to explore various substituents at the more tolerant N3-position of the quinazolinone core. Consequently, they replaced the N3-cyclopropyl group in 40 with the 1-methylcyclopropyl moiety, which led to the identification of 41, showing improved enzymatic and cellular potencies and PK profile (Figure 18). The X-ray crystal structure data revealed binding of the two methylcyclopropyl moieties into small hydrophobic pockets positioned under the glycine-rich loop of Pim-1 kinase. The authors concluded that this interaction may be responsible for the high potency and selectivity of 41 over other related kinases.

    Discovery of Veliparib (44)

    Poly(ADP-ribose)polymerase 1 (PARP1) inhibitors are useful for the treatment of various cancers as single agents or in combination with established chemotherapeutic agents. To this end, a series of cyclic amine-containing benzimidazole-4-carboxamide (BI-4-CONH2) catalytic inhibitors of PARP1 was reported by Penning and colleagues.(84) They found that the pyrrolidin-2-yl at the 2-position of the BI-4-CONH2 scaffold was a promising moiety to achieve low nanomolar biochemical and cellular potency as exemplified by compound 42 (PK profile not available). Next, they inserted the methyl substituent at C-2 position of the pyrrolidine ring, which ultimately led to the discovery of two tetrasubstituted carbon-containing enantiomers (S)-43 and (R)-44 (ABT-888/veliparib)(84) with marginally improved biochemical and cellular potencies. Though both enantiomers exhibited comparable in vitro potency, only the (R)-enantiomer (44) had a superior PK profile (Figure 19).

    Development of Leukotriene C4 Synthase (LTC4S) Inhibitors 45 and 46

    LTC4S catalyzes the conversion of LTA4 to LTC4 in a cascade that leads to asthma.(85) Munck Af Rosenschold et al. reported the synthesis of a pyrazine derivative containing an N-isobutyl group with picomolar potency against LTC4S and showing attractive cell-based potency, distribution coefficient, and low human hepatocyte intrinsic clearance.(85) Incorporation of a fluorine atom at the 2-position of the N-isobutyl group led to a tetrasubstituted carbon-containing analogue 46 (AZD9898) with retention of picomolar potency against LTC4S and improved hepatocyte clearance compared to 45 (Figure 20).(85) It may be noted that favorable hepatocyte clearance is a result of bioisosteric replacement of the hydrogen with a fluorine rather than the effect of quaternization.(86)

    Discovery of β-Arrestin Biased CNS Penetrating Neurotensin Receptor 1 (NTR1) Allosteric Modulators 47 and 48

    Since NTR1 is an emerging target for a wide range of CNS disorders, Pinkerton et al. pursued optimization of quinazoline derivatives as potent and CNS penetrating NTR1 allosteric modulators.(87) Of the various derivatives prepared, 47, bearing the N-methyl-2-hydroxyethylamine substituent at the C6-position of the quinazoline ring, demonstrated submicromolar efficacy against NTR1 and also demonstrated a promising response in terms of Emax (Figure 21). Next, they converted the tert-C1-cyclopropyl ring to the 1-fluoro substituted cyclopropyl ring (-H to -F isosteric replacement)(86)-containing analogue 48 (SBI-553) that showed marginally increased potency and response in addition to PK parameters that were suitable for further development.(87)

    Development of N-Methyl-d-Aspartate Receptor (NMDAR) Positive Allosteric Modulators (PAMs)

    NMDA receptors are implicated in a wide range of CNS disorders. Consequently, an endogenously produced neuroactive 24(S)-hydroxycholesterol 49, serving as an initial lead, was optimized by La and colleagues to develop more potent NMDA receptor PAMs with favorable PK profile.(88) The poor metabolic stability of 49 was suspected to be due to the phase 2 conjugation of the C3-OH group. Considering the essential role played by C3-OH group toward potency, the authors decided to sterically shield it by adding a methyl substituent to mitigate phase 2 metabolic inactivation. This has led to the identification of a metabolically stable C3-tetrasubstituted analogue 50, demonstrating a >4-fold increase in potency toward GluN2 and improved in vivo PK properties compared to 49. Further modification of 50 at the C24-position wherein an isopropyl group was replaced with a gem-dimethyl group led to the identification of 51 (SGE-301) bearing a second tetrasubstituted carbon (Figure 22).(88) Relative to 50, compound 51 displayed further improvement in PK properties and also enhanced long-term potentiation and cognition in rat models.

    Discovery of Estrogen Receptor α (ERα) Degraders 52 and 53

    Burks and co-workers reported the synthesis of various tetrahydroisoquinoline derivatives as potent ERα antagonists with the ability to selectively degrade ERα.(89) One of the early leads was compound 52, bearing a quaternary benzylic carbon and demonstrating an acceptable potency against ERα (Figure 23). Subsequently, they probed the significance of a methyl group connected to the benzylic carbon on ERα binding affinity by synthesizing and testing a des-methyl analogue of 52, but this proved to be a weaker ERα antagonist compared to 52 (the authors did not show these data). It was reasoned that the weaker activity of a des-methyl analogue was the result of the loss of van der Waals interactions between the methyl group and Leu346 within the ligand binding site of ERα as confirmed by subsequent X-ray crystal structure analysis. Therefore, they retained a tetrasubstituted benzylic carbon center in subsequent optimization work, leading to the potent ERα degrader 53. Although the (R)-stereochemistry at the tetrasubstituted benzylic chiral center of 53 demonstrated favorable affinity toward ERα, both the (R)- and (S)-isomers were shown to undergo fast racemization in a number of physiological conditions.

    Identification of Selective Estrogen Receptor Downregulator (SERD) Antagonists 54–57

    Incorporation of 1-methyl substituent in a promising SERD hit 54 led to a tetrasubstituted carbon-containing 55 with a drop in potency while gaining lipophilicity by 0.9 log unit.(90) Addition of a second methyl group at C3-position led to a quaternary carbon-containing 57 with decreased potency but noticeable advantages in terms of turnover in both rat and human hepatocytes compared to C3-tertiary analogue 56 (Figure 24).
    In a follow-on work, Scott and colleagues demonstrated the impact of quaternization of C1-position in 58.(91) For example, insertion of 1-methyl substituent led to a tetrasubstituted carbon-containing 59 with retention of ER binding potency, but the degradation potency was substantially dropped. Moreover, quaternization also resulted in a noticeable drop in the stability of 59 as assessed by 1H NMR and LC–MS analyses. To circumvent the stability concerns associated with 59, the authors subsequently decided to bridge the diaxial 1,3-methyl groups leading to the identification of a bridged tetracyclic indole scaffold 60 with improved stability; however, it showed lowered ER binding and ER degradation potencies compared to 59 (Figure 25). Thus, ER degrader examples indicate that quaternization of a secondary or a tertiary carbon does not always lead to improved pharmacodynamic or pharmacokinetic properties.

    Synthesis of Phenylindole-Based Inhibitors of AAA+ ATPase p97 Inhibitors 61 and 62

    Since p97 is as a potential anticancer target, LaPorte et al., optimized their early lead compound 61, which showed submicromolar potency against p97 (Figure 26).(92) They made two chemical modifications to 61: (1) insertion of a fluorine atom at the 5-position of the indole nucleus and (2) installation of a spirocyclobutane ring at the α-carbon adjacent to the N-methylpiperazine ring. These modifications led to the identification of 62 with a 14-fold increase in potency. On the basis of SAR studies around 2-phenylindole derivatives, it was reasoned that the enhanced potency of 62 was due to the combined contribution of (1) a hydrogen bond between a 5-fluorine and the side chain of Thr509 and (2) a spirocyclobutane providing a kinked N-methylpiperazine side chain that effectively occupies a deep hydrophobic pocket enclosed by residues Val493 and Ile531 of p97. The authors hypothesized that the more buried binding of the N-methylpiperazine could be the result of desolvation of the spirocyclobutyl moiety.

    Development of Cell Active SET and MYND Domain-Containing Protein 2 (SMYD2) Inhibitory Chemical Probes

    Since increased expression of SMYD2 has been shown in a number of cancer types,(93) Taylor and colleagues began the search for efficient cell active chemical probes targeted to SMYD2.(94) Toward this objective, the first lead compound 63 showed a low nanomolar biochemical inhibitory activity against SMYD2, but it exhibited poor cell-based activity in MCF7 cells (Figure 27). Consequently, 63 was not regarded as a useful chemical probe. This limitation was addressed by exploiting a small lipophilic notch observed in the crystal structure of the SMYD2-63 complex. To effectively fill this, they introduced a methyl group at the 3-position of the azetidine ring while simultaneously increasing compound lipophilicity for cellular permeability as in 64. Compound 64 exhibited increased cell-based potency while retaining the S-adenosylmethionine-competitive inhibitory biochemical potency of 63.

    Discovery of Human Neuromedin U Receptor 1 (NMUR1) Agonists 65 and 66

    NMUR1 is an emerging target for the development of antiobesity drugs. Takayama and co-workers reported the synthesis of 2-thienylacetyl hexapeptides as selective NMUR1 agonists with enhanced serum stability.(95) The hexapeptide analogue 65 showed highly selective agonist activity toward NMUR1 (EC50 > 0.25 nM), which was greater than toward NMUR2 (EC50 > 100 nM), but it suffered from rapid degradation by rat and human serum thrombin. To overcome this limitation, they synthesized the new hexapeptide analogue 66 bearing an α-methyl at Trp2, which not only improved potency and selectivity toward NMUR1 (EC50 = 0.25 nM) over NMUR2 (EC50 > 100 nM) but also enhanced stability in rat and human serum (Figure 28). The authors concluded that the α-methylation at Trp2 prevented efficient binding of this modified residue to the thrombin P4 aryl binding site. Furthermore, 66 significantly reduced the body weight of male ddY mice upon subcutaneous administration.

    Development of β-Site Amyloid Precursor Protein Cleaving Enzyme 1 (BACE1) Inhibitors 67–69

    BACE1, an aspartyl protease enzyme, plays a crucial role in the production of amyloid β in the brain. Therefore, it has been widely explored as a therapeutic target for the development of anti-Alzheimer’s drugs. A cyclopropylthiazine analogue 67 manifested low nanomolar biochemical and cell (HEK)-based potency against BACE1, but it lacked selectivity as evidenced from its potent inhibitory action on BACE2 activity. Therefore, it was optimized first at the P1′ and then at the P3 regions to enhance selectivity toward BACE1 and also to obtain new analogues with a CNS drug-like profile. Although insertion of a methoxymethyl substituent in the P1′ region as in 68 resulted in improved enzymatic and cell-based BACE1 inhibitory activity and P-gp efflux ratio, it retained high affinity toward BACE2. While retaining the P1′ methoxymethyl substituent on the tetrasubstituted carbon of the cyclopropylthiazine, the authors replaced the 5-chloropyridine P3 motif with a 5-propargyloxypyrazine ring to effectively fill the deeper S3 pocket of BACE1. These efforts resulted in the identification of 69 (AM-6494) with increased biochemical and cellular potency against BACE1, desirable selectivity over BACE2 and CatD and exhibited in vitro and in vivo CNS drug-like properties and efficacy (Figure 29).(96)

    Design of 71 (Misoprostol)

    Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID)-induced damage to gastric mucosa is a common problem associated with the chronic use of nonselective NSAIDs.(97) An exogenously administered natural prostaglandin PGE1 (70) was shown to reduce gastric damage. However, it was ineffective orally and parenteral administration led to the rapid degradation by prostaglandin-15-hydroxydehydrogenase-mediated oxidation of the C15-secondary alcohol group to an inactive C15-ketone metabolite. To address this concern, the prostaglandin derivative 71 (misoprostol) was developed for oral administration. Specifically, three chemical modifications were performed on 70: (1) the carboxyl group was converted to the methyl ester, which upon oral administration undergoes an esterase-mediated hydrolysis to the active carboxylic acid metabolite, (2) the hydroxyl group was relocated from the C15 to the C16 position to thwart the enzyme prostaglandin-15-hydroxydehydrogenase, and (3) successive insertion of a methyl group at the C16 was done, thus generating the stable tert-alcohol-containing derivative 71 (Figure 30).

    Discovery of HCV NS5B Polymerase Inhibitor 72 (Sofosbuvir)

    The nucleoside phosphoramidate prodrug 72 (sofosbuvir), a hepatitis C virus (HCV) NS5B polymerase inhibitor discovered by Sofia and co-workers, has been used for the treatment of chronic HCV infections (Figure 31).(98) Although 72 carries a 3′-hydroxyl group to serve as a nucleophile for an incoming nucleotide substrate, it acts as a terminator of the nascent RNA product. The chain termination activity of 72 is analogous to that of other related C2′-modified nucleoside analogues (Figure 31), i.e., the steric clash between the congested C2′-tetrasubstituted stereocenter and the incoming nucleoside triphosphate as well as the side chain of Ser282/Thr282 within the active site of HCV NS5B polymerase.(99,100) The C2′-tetrasubstituted stereocenter also allowed downward orientation of a fluorine atom to engage in favorable interactions with the side chain of Asn291. This interaction was critical for the recognition of the active form of 72 at the active site of HCV NS5B polymerase.(100) Several other tetrasubstituted C2’ motifs such as 2′-α-hydroxy-2′-β-methyl, 2′-α-fluoro-2′-β-chloro, 2′-deoxy-2′-spirooxetane, and 2′-deoxy-2′-spirocyclopropane are also shown to potently inhibit HCV NS5B polymerase by a similar mechanism (Figure 31).(101)

    Bromodomain and Extra-Terminal Protein (BET) Inhibitors 73 and 74

    BET is a well-established target for anticancer drug development. Although benzhydryl-containing 73 showed potent biochemical and cell-based potency, it suffered from unfavorable ligand lipophilic efficiency (LLE). To improve LLE, the diphenyl moiety in 73 was replaced with a bipyridyl moiety while simultaneously adding a methyl substituent at the benzylic carbon, which led to a tetrasubstituted carbon-containing derivative 74 with improved potency and LLE (Figure 32).(102)

    Discovery of Toll-like Receptor 8 (TLR8) Agonists 75–77

    Activation of TLR8 by small molecules has been hypothesized to stimulate host immune response, which in turn will provide a novel treatment strategy for chronic hepatitis B.(103) On the basis of this concept, Mackman and colleagues synthesized TLR8 selective derivative 75 showing submicromolar potency against IL-12p40 (TLR8 cytokine), but it had no effect on TLR7-mediated induction of IFN-α up to 50 μM and showed only 10-fold MT-4 cytotoxicity window.(104) To completely fill the lipophilic pocket of TLR8 from the α-branch point and minimize entropic penalty of the flexible hydroxymethyl substituent, the authors introduced an α-methyl group to obtain a tetrasubstituted carbon-containing 76 with improved potency and selectivity toward TLR8 which also resulted in significantly improved MT-4 cytotoxicity window. To mitigate metabolic modification of the pyridopyrimidine core, a 7-fluoro group was added, which gave rise to a clinical candidate 77 (GS-9688, selgantolimod) (Figure 33).(104)

    1,5-Benzodiazepines as Cholecystokinin A (CCK-A) Agonists 78 and 79

    Selective CCK-A agonists are useful in obese patients as satiety agents.(105) Willson and co-workers began optimization of one of the leads, 78, by inserting a methyl group at C3-position of the benzodiazepine scaffold, which led to quaternary carbon-containing 79 with increased functional efficacy and selectivity.(106) In contrast, incorporation of a methyl group at C3 in urea series as exemplified by 80 resulted in loss of functional efficacy and selectivity (Figure 34). Thus, 80 highlights a potential caveat that incorporation of a quaternary center does not always lead to improved ligand properties.

    Examples of Spirocycles in Drug Discovery

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Zheng et al. briefly reviewed the application of spirocyclic scaffolds in drug discovery with an emphasis on biological activities and provided examples reported during 2011–2015.(107,108) Muller et al. recently described the analysis of sp3-rich spirocycle-containing bioactive compounds and concluded that spirocyclic chemical space can be further expanded for drug discovery.(109)

    Discovery of Cyclophilin (CyP) A Inhibitors 81 and 82 with Potent Anti-HCV Activity

    Interaction of host CyP A and HCV NS5a protein has been suggested to play a role in the replication of HCV.(110,111) Therefore, disruption of host CyP A and HCV NS5a interaction represents a viable strategy to minimize HCV replication. Targeting CyP A by small molecules will also ensure high barrier to resistance and pan-genotypic activity. To that end, Mackman and co-workers decided to develop orally bioavailable nonimmunosuppressive small molecule CyP A inhibitors with potent anti-HCV efficacy.(112) They began with a sanglifehrin A inspired 22-membered macrocyclic lead 81, which, although a highly potent CyP A inhibitor, exhibited moderate anti-HCV potency and a poor PK profile. Therefore, 81 was subjected to further optimization to 82 by employing a number of modification strategies: (1) reducing the macrocycle ring size from 22 to 21, (2) swapping the lactone and the lactam groups, (3) replacing the styryl moiety with the quinoline ring, which resulted in the introduction of an intramolecular hydrogen bond (IMHB) and resultant increase in cell permeability, and (4) transforming a tertiary C14 to a quaternary C14 (spiro-1,3-dioxane) that resulted in a number of beneficial properties, including reduced oxidative metabolism, lowered log D value, and reduced liability of drug–drug interaction due to decreased activity toward pregnane X receptor. Additionally, 82 contains two less chiral centers and improved in vitro potency and PK profile compared to 81 (Figure 35).

    Discovery of Selective Tankyrase Inhibitors 83–86

    Similar to PARP1 inhibitors, tankyrase (TNKS1/PARP-5a and TNKS2/PARP-5b) inhibitors are also useful for the treatment of cancers. Shirai and colleagues began with the HTS hit optimized lead compound 83 that showed selective inhibition of TNKS1 and TNKS2 over PARP1 (Figure 36).(113) From the X-ray crystal study, the authors observed that the tetrahydroquinazolinone core and the terminal phenyl ring were orthogonal to each other. These observations prompted them to lock this orthogonality via installation of a spiroindoline ring at the 4-position of the piperidine ring to obtain 84 with improved enzyme potency, selectivity, aqueous solubility, and metabolic stability but slightly diminished cell-based potency. Subsequently, 84 was optimized by addition of fluorine and hydroxyethyl substituents on the spiroindoline ring to obtain 85 (RK-287107)(113) with further increase in enzymatic potency, selectivity, cell-based potency, and aqueous solubility; however, its metabolic stability was lower than that of 84. To improve microsomal stability and P-gp efflux ratio of 85, it was investigated further by subjecting it to chemical derivatization that led to the discovery of 86 (RK-582) with improved microsomal stability and P-gp efflux ratio (Figure 36).(114) Additionally, when administered orally 86 showed improved inhibition of tumor growth in a mouse xenograft model. The X-ray crystal structure of 86 bound to TNKS2 highlighted productive interactions between the spiroindolinone moiety and the TNKS2 residues. For instance, the phenyl portion of the indolinone moiety was engaged in T-shaped π–π and CH−π interactions with the side chains of Phe1035 and Ile1075, respectively. The carbonyl oxygen of the indolinone forms a water-mediated hydrogen bonding interaction with the backbone −NH– of Tyr1060. The 2,6-dimethylmorpholine moiety at the 6-position of the spiroindolinone core is localized outside the enzyme binding pocket.(114)

    Development of β-Site Amyloid Precursor Protein Cleaving Enzyme 1 (BACE1) Inhibitors 87–91

    Thomas and co-workers reported the development of chroman derivatives as potent and selective BACE1 inhibitors.(115) A des-methyl (tert-carbon-containing) analogue 87 showed moderate biochemical- and cell-based potency. Insertion of a β-methyl group gave rise to a tetrasubstituted carbon-containing analogue 88, which demonstrated significant improvement in biochemical- and cell-based potency and also exhibited noticeable selectivity over physiologically important CatD. On the basis of the results obtained from the X-ray crystal structure, the authors concluded that the increase in potency of 88 toward BACE1 was the result of a favorable hydrophobic contact between the side chain of Thr132 and the β-methyl group. The greater selectivity of 88 toward BACE1 than toward CatD was reasoned to be due to the severe steric clash of the β-methyl group with the flexible loop of CatD. Because 88 had unfavorable P-gp efflux ratio, it was further modified by replacing the fluoropyridine ring with the cyanophenyl ring to obtain 89, which demonstrated further increase in potency and selectivity and a desirable efflux ratio (Figure 37).
    Fujimoto and colleagues undertook optimization of lead compound 90, which showed low nanomolar potency against BACE1 but moderate selectivity over BACE2.(116) On the basis of the X-ray crystal study, the authors found that a greater selectivity for BACE1 over BACE2 was achievable by adding a spirocyclic ring at the 5-position of the thiazine ring as in 91, which led to a significant jump in BACE1 selectivity. The X-ray structure of 91 bound to BACE1 demonstrated a favorable interaction between the 5-spirotetrahydro-2H-thiopyran 1,1-dioxide and the side chain of Tyr71 in the flap region. The binding of 91 to BACE2 revealed a significant movement of the flap region, which could account for its greater selectivity for BACE1 than for BACE2 (Figure 37). A marginal drop in cell-based potency of 91 was attributed to its less lipophilic nature (log D pH7.4 = 0.62).

    Development of the Potent and Metabolically Stable κ-Opioid Receptor Agonist 93

    Sherwood and colleagues began their search for a potent κ-opioid receptor agonist using naturally occurring non-nitrogenous salvinorin A (92) scaffold as a starting point, which showed potent agonist activity toward the κ-opioid receptor.(117) Nevertheless, one of the major liabilities associated with 92 is the presence of a readily hydrolyzable acetate ester group on A ring and ensuing short half-life that precludes in vivo evaluation. Since the C2-acetoxy group has been shown to engage in activity-favoring hydrogen bonding interaction with the κ-opioid receptor, the authors decided to protect it through the formation of a conformationally constrained tetrasubstituted carbon-containing spirobutyrolactone. This chemical modification gave 93 with a potency comparable to that of 92 but with a greater resistance to metabolism by rat liver microsomes (Figure 38). 93 also demonstrated potent attenuation of nociceptive and inflammatory pain in mice.

    Discovery of Histone Acetyltransferase (HAT) Inhibitors 94–96

    Since the inhibition of HAT is considered a strategy for anticancer drug development, Michaelides et al. optimized a virtual screening hit that culminated in lead 94 with micromolar inhibitory activity against HAT.(118) Subsequently they decided to restrict the conformational flexibility of the pendant phenyl ring in an effort to improve potency. This resulted in the identification of a constrained spiroindene hydantoin derivative 95 with a >4-fold increase in potency. Further optimization of 95 led to urea substituted spiroindene oxazolidinedione 96 (A-485)(118) with nanomolar potency against HAT (Figure 39).

    Human Mitochondrial Peptide Deformylase (HsPDF) Inhibitors 97–99

    HsPDF catalyzes the deformylation of N-terminal formylmethionines of newly synthesized mitochondrial proteins.(119) HsPDF has been shown to be overexpressed in a variety of cancer cells, including breast, lung, and colon cancer.(120) Hu and co-workers identified a quaternary carbon-containing 5-azaspiro[2.4]heptane derivative 97 via screening of their compound collection.(121)97 showed single-digit nanomolar enzyme potency against HsPDF and a double-digit micromolar cytotoxicity toward HCT116 cells. They verified the beneficial effect of the P2-binding spirocyclopropane moiety by testing 98 and found it to be less effective compared to 97. By retaining P1- and P2-binding motifs intact, they replaced the P3-binding 5-fluoropyridine ring and the carboxamide group with a 4-fluoro-2-trifluoromethylphenyl ring and amide isostere 1,2,4-oxadiazole, respectively, to obtain 99 with further increase in enzymatic and cell-based potencies (Figure 40).

    Discovery of Calcitonin Gene-Related Peptide Receptor (CGRPR) Antagonist 100 (Ubrogepant)

    CGRPR and its ligand CGRP are implicated in the pathophysiology of migraine and thus serve as targets for the development of antimigraine drugs.(122,123) A complete report on the discovery of 100 is not available, but based on a series of structurally related derivatives, it can be concluded that the spirocyclic 4-azaindene nucleus locks the hydrogen bond acceptor–donor pair in a favorable geometry to form productive hydrogen bonding interactions with the backbone Thr122 on CGRPR (Figure 41).(124)

    Aldose Reductase (AR) Inhibitors 101–103

    AR inhibitors are useful for the treatment of diabetic complications.(125) AR inhibitors typically consist of an acetic acid group or five-membered cyclic imides such as hydantoin or succinimide. Because of the poor in vivo activity of the acetic acid class, newer AR inhibitors instead contain tetrasubstituted carbon stereocenter-containing spirocyclic succinimide (e.g., 101(126,127) and 102 (AS-3201)(128)) or hydantoin (e.g., 103)(127) acidic functionalities (Figure 42). The anionic spirosuccinimide or spirohydantoin motif has been considered as a quintessential structural feature to efficiently bind to the anionic binding site surrounded by positively charged amino acids and nicotinamide portion of NADP+ within the active site of AR. These spirocycles drive the bioactive conformational shape by arranging the hydantoin/succinimide moiety and the bicyclic ring system perpendicular to each other.(126,129,130)

    Discovery of 105 (Tofogliflozin)

    Inhibition of sodium glucose cotransporter 2 (SGLT2) leads to the excretion of glucose into the urine. Therefore, SGLT2 inhibitors are used as type 2 antidiabetic drugs. Ohtake and co-workers conducted active ligand-based virtual screening of compound database using two-point pharmacophore model (encompassing the sugar moiety and the aromatic ring), which led to the identification of the spiroketal C-arylglucoside 104.(131) Subsequent removal of unnecessary acyl groups and addition of a para-ethylbenzyl moiety on the spiro-dihydroisobenzofuran core yielded the highly selective and potent SGLT2 inhibitor 105 (CSG452/tofogliflozin) (Figure 43).(131)

    Discovery of Ibutamoren (107) and Capromorelin (108)

    107 and 108 are orally active peptidomimetic agonists of growth hormone secretagogue receptor (GHSR). The spiropiperidine core of lead 106 is a privileged scaffold for a number of GPCR targeted ligands. Consequently, Patchett and colleagues chemically modified 106 by replacing tryptophan, quinuclidinyl urea, and spiroindene with (d)-benzyloxyserine, α-aminoisobutyramide, and N-substituted spiroindoline, respectively, to obtain 107 (MK-0677, ibutamoren) with significantly improved efficacy (Figure 44).(132)
    Compound 107 had a poor PK profile due to the presence of a dipeptidyl backbone. Since the dipeptidyl backbone is essential for GHSR agonist activity, Carpino et al. decided to pursue a PK-driven optimization strategy to improve the physicochemical properties of 107 by focusing on the C-terminal region while retaining the essential dipeptide pharmacophore.(133) Replacing the N-substituted spiroindolinepiperidine core by the 3aR-benzyl substituted piperidinopyrazolinone scaffold gave 108 with increased lipophilicity to compensate the hydrophilicity imposed by the dipeptidyl backbone (Figure 44).

    Discovery of Transient Receptor Potential Vanilloid Subtype 4 (TRPV4) Inhibitors 109–111

    TRPV4-mediates Ca2+ influx across the plasma membrane, and thus it serves as a target for the treatment of pulmonary edema.(134) Brooks and co-workers reported the synthesis of a benzimidazole-based spirocyclic multiple quaternary carbon-containing clinical candidate as a potent inhibitor of TRPV4.(135) They began with the HTS screening hit molecule 109 that showed potent TRPV4 inhibition with attractive physicochemical properties but exhibited undesirably short mean residence time (MRT) in rat model (Figure 45). To improve MRT and potency, they installed a methyl group onto the cyclohexane ring to sterically block potential metabolism at the methylene bridge. These efforts led to the identification of 110, which demonstrated a 32-fold increase in potency but no improvement in MRT. The improved potency was ascribed to a reduced conformational flexibility at the cyclohexane or benzimidazole rings and to the ensuing reduced entropic penalty upon binding to TRPV4. To remove potential oxidation liability of the neopentyl moiety on the oxazolidinone ring nitrogen, they introduced a gem-dimethylcarbinol substituted pyrazine ring to obtain a clinical candidate 111 (GSK2798745) with increased MRT and desirable rat PK profile.(135)

    Discovery of Polo-like Kinase 4 (PLK4) Inhibitors 112–114

    PLK4 is a serine–threonine kinase that is implicated in triple-negative breast cancer and other tumor types.(136) Sampson and colleagues began a PLK4 inhibitor development effort with the early lead compound (E)-112 that showed potent PLK4 inhibition but demonstrated poor oral exposure.(137) Furthermore, the (E)-C3-arylidene double bond in 112 was prone to undergo E/Z isomerization under in vivo conditions. To address this problem, the authors decided to introduce configurational stability while simultaneously improving physicochemical properties by replacing the double bond with an isosteric cyclopropane ring. This strategy resulted in the trans-locked 113 with improved potency, KDR selectivity, and DMPK profile. The cyclopropane ring of 113 is orthogonal to the plane of the oxindole ring, which caused disruption of crystal packing forces and thus increased aqueous solubility. The addition of a 5-methoxy group to the oxindole ring resulted in 114 with further increase in potency, selectivity, and oral exposure (Figure 46).

    Discovery of Signal Peptide Peptidase-like 2a (SPPL2a) Inhibitors 115–117

    SPPL2a, an aspartyl intramembrane protease, plays a key role in antigen presenting B cell maturation.(138) Therefore, inhibition of SPPL2a is a strategy for the treatment of autoimmune diseases. Velcicky and colleagues synthesized the tricyclic benzopyrazolodiazepinone lead 115, which showed reasonable potency and selectivity toward SPPL2a over γ-secretase and an acceptable PK profile.(139) The tricyclic ring system of 115 was successively optimized to block a metabolically prone benzylic carbon by converting it into a carbonyl group. However, since this modification will produce a relatively polar molecule, they also replaced the methyl group by a cyclopropyl group to obtain 116, possessing a log P value comparable to that of 115. Unfortunately, 116 was less potent than 115. Finally, the addition of a spirocyclopropane moiety to the tricyclic scaffold of 116 led to the identification of 117 possessing greater lipophilicity, comparable potency, and improved PK profile compared to 115 (Figure 47).

    Spirocycle/Quaternary Carbon-Containing MDM2-p53 Interaction Inhibitors

    The MDM2 (murine double minute 2) oncogene antagonizes tumor suppressor protein p53 via a protein–protein interaction. Inhibition of the MDM2-p53 interaction by small molecules would be expected to release p53 from MDM2 and thus activate wild-type p53 pathway and produce an antitumor effect.(140) Interaction of p53 with the MDM2 occurs primarily through three hydrophobic residues Phe19, Trp23, and Leu26. Thus, MDM2 has three docking pockets (Phe19, Trp23, and Leu26) for p53 that could be exploited by nonpeptidic small molecules to block the MDM2-p53 interaction. Consequently, a large number of MDM2 directed small molecules bearing spirocycles/quaternary carbon centers have been developed and of which only selected examples are shown in Figure 48. Spirooxindole-based MDM2 inhibitors 118 (MI-888)(141) and 119 (MI-77301/SAR405838)(142) wherein the two halogenated phenyl moieties are held in a trans-arrangement by a rigid spirooxindolylpyrrolidine have been developed by the Wang group. A quaternary stereocenter-containing piperidinone MDM2 inhibitor exemplified by 120 (AMG 232), also analogously featuring two essential halogenated phenyl moieties in the trans-orientation, was developed by Rew and colleagues.(143)

    Synthesis of Lysine-Specific Demethylase 1 (LSD1) Inhibitors 121 and 122

    Overexpression of LSD1 is implicated in a wide range of cancers. Therefore, Gehling and colleagues decided to identify a novel class of covalent inhibitors of LSD1.(144) One of the early lead compounds 121, typified by the LSD1 bound flavin adenine dinucleotide (FAD) cofactor targeted warhead styrenylcyclopropylamine, showed low nanomolar potency in biochemical enzyme, lymphocyte antigen 96 (LY96) gene, and phenotypic Kasumi-1 cell assays. Since 121 manifested less than desirable microsomal clearance in mouse, rat, dog, and human microsomes, it was optimized by replacing the piperidine ring with its surrogate 2-azaspiro[3.3]heptane ring to obtain 122 with overall improved potency and liver microsomal clearance profile (Figure 49).

    General Principles That Can Be Gathered from a Quaternary or Tetrasubstituted Carbon in Terms of Potency, Selectivity, Metabolism, Lipophilicity, Solubility, Enthalpy, and Entropy

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    (1) It is generally anticipated that quaternization of a secondary or tertiary carbon will enhance binding affinity and selectivity to target receptor simply via gaining an access to the unique out-of-plane vacant target pocket and capturing specific favorable interactions. This exercise may allow medicinal chemists to tune the three-dimensional molecular shape to achieve desirable on target binding profile. However, it should be noted that substitution at the vacant vertices of a secondary or tertiary carbon occasionally becomes counterproductive and outcomes of which vary based on the individual binding site topology as described in the potential caveat section.
    (2) Metabolic hydroxylation of tertiary −C–H bonds with increased s-character in a quaternary carbon-containing BCP system is less likely to occur compared to the aromatic −C–H bonds. Numerous examples described in this Perspective indicate that quaternization of a secondary or tertiary carbon led to improvement in in vitro and in vivo DMPK profiles.
    (3) Addition of a hydrophobic quaternary or tetrasubstituted (sp3) carbon in lead compounds may increase lipophilicity, but aqueous solubility may increase, if not decrease, by a potential disruption of molecular planarity as evidenced from examples 12, 26, and 113. Converting the benzylic carbon into a quaternary center may give rise to compounds with improved aqueous solubility by increased solvation and poorer solid state crystal lattice packing, e.g., 12, 41, and 113. Occasionally medicinal chemists need to increase both solubility and hydrophobicity to achieve the desired oral bioavailability, a task that may potentially be achieved by replacing the aromatic ring with a quaternary carbon aliphatic ring system such as BCP.
    (4) A quaternary carbon in the form of a spiro atom, when present in the core structure, inherently provides an opportunity to project substituents in all three dimensions to maximize ligand interactions with a three-dimensional target binding site. The other prominent feature of spirocyclic compounds is the conformational rigidity, which allows ligands to bind to the target protein in an entropically favorable manner. Increased sp3 character of spirocycles further favors aqueous solubility.
    (5) Entropy gain through quaternization of a secondary or tertiary carbon may be derived from a high degree of steric congestion in preorganized lead compounds. However, it remains to be validated by comparing relevant quaternary/tetrasubstituted carbon-containing MMPs.
    (6) Although predicting the effect of a structural modification on enthalpy or entropy of binding is difficult, some general trends can be gathered from structural modification at the sp3 carbon center. For example, addition of a polar group such as amino or hydroxyl at a tertiary carbon-containing lead molecule may result in favorable enthalpy, provided these groups are engaged in hydrogen bonding interaction with out-of-plane active site residues. Similarly, addition of a small hydrophobic group such as methyl, ethyl, isopropyl, or cyclopropyl may contribute to a favorable enthalpy via van der Waals contacts and by decreasing desolvation enthalpy while simultaneously gaining favorable entropy by the expulsion of a weakly bound active site water molecule(s). Additionally, increase in LLE strongly correlates with the quality of lead compounds as assessed by enthalpy-driven binding(145) and evidenced from at least one example, i.e., BET inhibitor 74.
    (7) Quaternization has also been shown to impart stability of peptidic compounds against proteolytic cleavage (e.g., NMUR1 agonist 66). A strategy to install tetrasubstituted carbon as in 71 resulted in enhanced chemical and enzymatic stability. However, occasionally quaternization may result in chemical instability of the compound, e.g., ER degrader 59).

    Potential Caveats of a Tetrasubstituted or Quaternary Carbon

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    (1) Synthesis and SAR optimization of quaternary carbon-containing lead molecules may potentially pose limitations in terms of slowness of parallel synthesis due to stereochemical complexity.
    (2) Construction of quaternary carbon-containing small molecules presents a formidable synthetic challenge due to its inherent sterically crowded nature. It is important to distinguish quaternary carbons located within the core structure from those that arise due to peripheral quaternization, of which the former would be more challenging to construct and more difficult in terms of SAR interpretation.
    (3) Replacing the (hetero)aromatic ring participating in favorable π–π interactions or π–cation interactions with the sp3-rich ring may be counterproductive. Thus, it is imperative to identify such pharmacophoric rings prior to initiating drug-like property optimization program.
    (4) Large-scale production of architecturally complex quaternary carbon-containing GMP quality clinical candidates with several chiral centers will be challenging and may not be cost-effective. However, a growing list of the quaternary/tetrasubstituted carbon-containing compounds entering development or the clinic highlights the growth in this area (see subsequent section).
    (5) It is evident from this Perspective that quaternization of a secondary or a tertiary carbon does not always lead to improved pharmacodynamic or pharmacokinetic properties.
    (6) A simple quaternization by insertion of a methyl group at a tertiary carbon may result in increased lipophilicity, introduce potential sites for metabolism, and potentially lower potency due to a steric clash with protein or causing the conformation to deviate from the bioactive one.

    Quaternary or Tetrasubstituted Carbon-Containing Molecules That Entered Development

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    A noticeable number of quaternary or tetrasubstituted carbon-containing compounds that entered the development stage show the feasibility of clinical development of such architecturally complex molecules (Figure 50). For example, (R)-44 (veliparib) is undergoing phase 3 clinical trials in combination with numerous chemotherapeutic agents to treat a wide range of cancer patients.(146−149) MDM2 inhibitor 120 is in phase 1b/2a clinical trial for the treatment of metastatic melanoma (NCT02110355). 111, a TRPV4 inhibitor, is undergoing phase 2 clinical trial in participants with chronic cough (NCT03372603). 39, an ERK1/2 inhibitor, is undergoing phase 1 clinical trial in combination with pembrolizumab in participants with colorectal cancer (NCT02972034). Ibutamoren (107), an investigational new drug, has been clinically evaluated in phase 2 clinical trial, last updated in 2012 (NCT00116129), but no information is available on its further development. Selgantolimod (77), a TLR8 agonist, is undergoing phase 2 clinical trial in chronic hepatitis B patients (NCT03491553). Delgocitinib (123), a spirocycle-containing JAK inhibitor, has been approved for the treatment of atopic dermatitis in Japan. A tetrasubstituted stereocenter-containing nonsteroidal glucocorticoid receptor modulator, 124, has completed phase 1 clinical trial as a topical agent for psoriasis (NCT02940002). Numerous quaternary or tetrasubstituted carbon-containing drugs are in the clinic, including misoprostol (71), sofosbuvir (72), ubrogepant (100), tofogliflozin (105), aliskiren (125), lemborexant (126), and rolapitant (127).
    Large-scale production of GMP quality quaternary or tetrasubstituted carbon-containing clinical candidates strengthens the feasibility of developing these types of molecules (Figure 50). For example, the scale-up of a potential macrocyclic clinical candidate 128 (DZ-2384) bearing a quaternary stereocenter has been reported using electrochemical macrocyclization.(150,151) Maddess et al. reported the synthesis of multikilogram quantities of a quaternary carbon-containing estrogen receptor β agonist, 129, to facilitate early preclinical and clinical studies.(152) Sclafani et al. reported asymmetric pilot scale synthesis of a quaternary stereocenter-containing Nav1.7 and Nav1.8 voltage-gated sodium channel blocker funapide (130, TV-45070).(153) Cumming et al. reported multikilogram scale stereoselective synthesis of a novel anti-inflammatory agent (131, PH46A),(154) which has completed phase 1 clinical trial (BioMed Central ISRCTN Registry, 2014). Dillon et al. developed a kilogram-scale synthesis of tetrasubstituted carbon-containing muscarinic antagonist 132 (PF-3635659) to support clinical studies.(155) This compound has been investigated in phase 2 clinical trial in COPD patients (NCT01033487). A multikilogram scale synthesis of BACE inhibitor (133, LY2886721) has been reported using a pilot scale flow synthesis.(156) This compound has been evaluated in a number of clinical trials in healthy participants and participants with Alzheimer’s disease (NCT01807026).

    Summary

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Although combinatorial synthesis of small molecule libraries has been in place since the 1990s, it did not deliver clinically viable lead compounds.(157−161) This situation could be attributed to the use of synthetically tractable random/flat building blocks to generate combinatorial libraries.(157−161) On the contrary, the utilization of quaternary carbon stereocenters in small bioactive molecules is expected to pave the way for tapping into untrammeled patentable chemical space with a high likelihood of finding novel clinical candidate(s).(7,15,16,26,27) For this to become a reality, we need a quantum leap in the development of novel synthetic methods to construct quaternary carbon stereocenters in an enantiomerically pure form. The use of quaternary or tetrasubstituted carbon center during lead optimization will continue to grow owing to an increased awareness of the need for useful and potent drugs with a larger fraction of sp3 carbons.(7,15,16,26,27) The addition of one or more quaternary carbon centers in bioactive molecules will undoubtedly increase the cost of lead optimization and will slow down the process of lead-to-drug optimization. However, we may not require exhaustive SAR to arrive at a potentially viable clinical candidate because such molecules are expected to provide desirable three-dimensionality and drug-like property profiles. In addition, quaternary or tetrasubstituted carbon stereocenters will afford molecules that are relatively more resistant to racemization compared to the molecules bearing tertiary carbon stereocenters. This is of particular interest in situations where one isomer is a eutomer (pharmacologically active) but the other is a distomer (potentially harmful).
    The other type of quaternary carbon stereocenter, present as a spirocyclic ring system, is found in a number of synthetic, semisynthetic, and naturally occurring bioactive compounds. Spirocyclic compounds are denoted by molecules wherein two rings are connected by a single quaternary carbon center, referred to as a spiroatom. The spiroatom is expected to offer an element of chirality when the two rings are of different size, atomic composition, or substitution pattern. Because of its rigid three-dimensionality, a spirocycle has been widely employed in drug discovery to the extent that it has become a privileged scaffold for a number of therapeutic targets, including the CGRP receptor, BACE1, aldose reductase, protein–protein interaction (MDM2-p53), and HCV NS3/4a protease/NS5B polymerase/NS5A replication complex. When the spirocycle is present in the center of bioactive molecules, it imparts significant conformational rigidity, which in turn contributes to their entropically favorable binding to target proteins.
    It is hoped that this Perspective will encourage the practicing chemist to develop novel enantioselective methods for constructing quaternary or tetrasubstituted carbon stereocenters and for using them in the development of new drugs that will satisfy pressing therapeutic needs.

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
